title: Which country was affected the most, proportionally, by casualties during WW1? - Quora

response.answer_text: Mr. Mueller gave a terrific answer with Serbia. Certainly that is correct in terms of pure casualties as a proportion of population. Serbia’s role in WW1 is usually underplayed; in fact, it was Serb/Slav nationalism that really started the war, together with Austria’s leadership wanting to retaliate for that. The Crown Prince was not the real reason, that was a mere pretext for Austria to charge into Serbia—they would have found another one. Germany made a bad bargain in its alliance with Austria. An interesting point is that Kaiser Wilhelm actually tried repeatedly to back off on the war and restrain Austria. German generals believed the Schlieffen Plan could win, but (almost inevitably) the generals drew down the forces available to the northern attack (so the French could not humiliate them by crossing the border in the South), and it ran out of steam. In a sense, Germany was the most “affected” by its casualties, since the tremendous losses (for nothing!) and the Versailles Treaty laid the scene for a Hitler to come along with a remapping of what happened: Und Ihr habt doch gewonnen! (And you actually won!). Russia was fundamentally “affected by” its casualties, with the humiliation of so many losses (and bread riots) leading to the overthrow of the Tsar and the government. The Tsar was a dictator and horrible, but Stalin was much more efficient in how he enforced his dictatorship.

proportionally ? Serbia suffered around 22 % of the whole population as casualties, hard to estimate but between 750,000 and over 1.3 millions. Then France with 15 % of the population, 6.175.000 casulaties. ps: casulaties = wounded/killed/missing/prisonneers
